{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient has ingested an unknown poison and presents with signs of respiratory depression (rapid breathing), hypotension (blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg) and tachycardia (heart rate 103/min). The breath smells like kerosene, suggesting the presence of hydrocarbons. In this scenario, gastric lavage may not be useful as it is likely too late to remove the poison. Atropine is commonly used in anticholinergic poisoning, but its administration depends on the signs and symptoms of the patient. Vasopressors are not necessary at this stage.
